history.content: You can definitely get an A in CS61B. If you can't declare CS and you really want to study CS, maybe the backup majors (Data Science, CogSci) could be a good bet?
I am doubtful that is it possible to "transfer back to CC and take some Physics and Chem then re-apply to all the UCs with EECS instead".

children.subject: For me, CS70 was the hardest. You can probably get really good grades (A-, A) in 61A and 61B studying many hours a day and doing all the practice exams. CS70 you need to develop mathematical maturity which you may not be able to brute force in one semester to an A level without doing it before. So I would recommend expecting B, B+ for CS70 and trying to maximize 61 series score.

history.content:
Hi everyone!
I'm a transfer student this Fall, and I'd like to hear some advice from you guys.

I'm taking CS61A, EE16A, and CS70 this semester.

Question 1:

If I get B+ in CS61A and B in CS70, should I continue to study CS61B (with Joshua A. Hug) in the Spring 2018?

Is there a chance for me to get 3.30 total GPA in these three classes to declare CS Major?

Question 2:

If I get B+ in CS61A and B- in CS70, should I transfer back to my CC and take some Physics and Chem then re-apply to all the UCs with EECS instead?

Thank you and have a wonderful Winter Break, everyone.
history.subject: Declaring CS
